posts.cooked:
I’ve created a Pathplanner auto routine that picks up two notes. I want to add functionality so that if the first note is not picked up because another robot picked it up first, the robot runs a separate path to the note next to it. We have a prox sensor on our intake command that isFinished() when it trips. Is it possible to do this with the parallel race and deadline groups? In other words, if the intake command is never finished, start the Missed Note Path, and if the intake command is finished, go back to the speaker to shoot. The Right 3 Note Part 7 path in the image starts where the robot is blue. Will this work as is or do I have to switch some of the groups around? Thanks! Screenshot 2024-03-29 at 7.32.59 PM 2880×1718 472 KB

Screenshot 2024-03-29 at 7.32.59 PM 2880×1718 472 KB

Screenshot 2024-03-29 at 7.32.59 PM 2880×1718 472 KB

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
No, you need a conditional command to do this.

In general I strongly recommend against using PathPlanner’s GUI to orchestrate complex whole-robot autonomous commands.  Consider instead using the PathPlanner commands to toggle Trigger s to which you bind other robot actions in code.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked: you could add a parallel race group with the isIntaked Command and a sequential command group that waits for x time and then does the path. that way if the intaked command ends it will end the group and not run the path and if it doesn’t then it will run the path.

It might be good to only make the robot paths in path planner but then set up the sequences in your robot container and use autoBuilder.followPath(String) to get the movement commands. It is easier to structure these complex autos in robot container where you don’t have to make named commands too.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Yeah, but you can’t easily continue the branched structure in a natural way if you do that.

Command composition is a powerful tool but it alone is not the best way to solve every problem.  Many subsystem interactions are betted represented in an event-based paradigm, by offloading the control logic into Trigger s instead.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
Path Planner is pretty decent at pathing on the fly.

I would recommend charting the auton so that it plans to grab and shoot each note in sequence, and to use the idea of a “finish_if_no_note” command racing with the “drive back and shoot” sequence.

Then if the robot has no note, it will skip the drive back and shoot sequence and automatically path find to the “pick up note 2” sequence which occurs after it.

It’s definitely a hack, and if you have time and the ability to simulate/test, I’d recommend what others here have said and rolling your own logic in the code, but I think a “finish_if_no_note” command is a very useful bandaid for you to use on the fly

posts.name: gcschmit
posts.cooked: I’ll echo the conditional command recommendation. Your auto command can be a composition of several PathPlanner autos. Here’s an example .
